evidence.text: Under federal law, hospitals that receive federal Medicare funds are required to provide necessary stabilizing treatment to patients who arrive at their emergency departments while experiencing a medical emergency.

extracted.value: Hospitals that receive federal Medicare funds are required to provide EMTALA treatment to patients who arrive at their emergency departments while experiencing a medical emergency.

evidence.text: Under the Emergency Medical Treatment and Labor Act (EMTALA), if a person with an “emergency medical condition” seeks treatment at an emergency department at a hospital that accepts Medicare funds, the hospital must provide medical treatment necessary to stabilize that condition before transferring or discharging the patient.

extracted.value: Under EMTALA, if a person with an “emergency medical condition” seeks treatment at an emergency department at a hospital that accepts Medicare funds, the hospital must provide medical treatment necessary to stabilize that condition before transferring or discharging the patient.

evidence.text: Crucially, “emergency medical conditions” under the statute include not just conditions that present risks to life but also those that place a patient’s “health” in “serious jeopardy” or risk “serious impairment to bodily functions” or “serious dysfunction of any bodily organ or part.”

extracted.value: EMTALA’s definition of an emergency medical condition includes conditions that place a patient’s “health” in serious jeopardy, risk serious impairment to bodily functions, or serious dysfunction of any bodily organ or part.

evidence.text: Such circumstances may include, but are not limited to, ectopic pregnancy, severe preeclampsia, or a pregnancy complication threatening septic infection or hemorrhage.

extracted.value: Circumstances where abortion is required under EMTALA include ectopic pregnancy, severe preeclampsia, or a pregnancy complication threatening septic infection or hemorrhage.

evidence.text: The State of Idaho, however, has passed a near‑absolute ban on abortion. Once the Idaho law takes effect on August 25, 2022, Idaho Code § 18‑622 will make it a felony to perform an abortion in all but extremely narrow circumstances.

extracted.value: The State of Idaho passed a near‑absolute ban on abortion effective August 25, 2022; Idaho Code § 18‑622 makes it a felony to perform an abortion in all but extremely narrow circumstances.

evidence.text: Under the Idaho law, once effective, any state or local prosecutor can subject a physician to indictment, arrest, and prosecution merely by showing that an abortion has been performed, without regard to the circumstances.

extracted.value: After the Idaho law takes effect, any state or local prosecutor can indict, arrest, and prosecute a physician solely for performing an abortion, regardless of circumstances.

evidence.text: The law then puts the burden on the physician to prove an “affirmative defense” at trial.

extracted.value: The Idaho law places the burden on the physician to prove an affirmative defense at trial.

evidence.text: Idaho’s abortion law will therefore prevent doctors from performing abortions even when a doctor determines that abortion is the medically necessary treatment to prevent severe risk to the patient’s health and even in cases where denial of care will likely result in death.

extracted.value: Idaho’s abortion law will prevent doctors from performing abortions even when a doctor determines it is medically necessary to prevent severe risk to the patient’s health or likely death.

evidence.text: Before filing this lawsuit, on July 29, 2022, the United States sent a letter to the State of Idaho, expressing the United States’ view that § 18‑622 was contrary to federal law.

extracted.value: On July 29, 2022, the United States sent a letter to the State of Idaho expressing that § 18‑622 was contrary to federal law.

evidence.text: The United States seeks a declaratory judgment that Idaho’s law is invalid under the Supremacy Clause and is preempted by federal law to the extent that it conflicts with EMTALA. The United States also seeks an order preliminarily and permanently enjoining Idaho’s restrictive abortion law to the extent it conflicts with EMTALA.

extracted.value: The United States seeks a declaratory judgment that Idaho’s law is invalid under the Supremacy Clause and is preempted by federal law where it conflicts with EMTALA, and also seeks a preliminary and permanent injunction against Idaho’s restrictive abortion law.
